Subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=12653864; y=fWut0pGcVrC_bl-RPP06i8f7opEaLabvYr1chQnoiQirl2vH

Cedric Beust wrote:

> When I try to optimize the speed of my tests, the first thing I do is appy
> the principle "Don't Repeat Yourself".  

DRY is about not repeating yourself in source code. It doesn't mean 
don't repeat at run time. It is a principle of code clarity, not a 
principle of optimization. What is a loop but a set of statements 
repeated a few thousand times at run time but only once in code? Indeed, 
a compiler might even unroll the loop so the compiled code repeats itself.

When I try to optimize anything, including test suites, the first thing 
I do is profile. If the profiler shows I'm spending a lot of time doing 
setup work, I'll try to optimize that away. If it doesn't show that, I 
won't waste my time making the code less clear. Optimizing tests is no 
different than optimizing anything else. Optimization in absence of real 
data is at best pointless and at worst actively harmful. It usually 
makes code less clear for no measurable speed gain.

I have indeed profiled my test suites, and so far I've only found 
occasional cases where repeated  test setup via constructors or setUp 
methods was a noticeable hot spot. In those few cases I've taken steps 
to eliminate the repeated initialization, often by moving fixtures into 
local variables. However, well over 90% of the time the cost of test 
initialization and the construction of TestCase objects has been 
negligible.

--
